title: Failed to type resolve function call in scrutinee tuple in match expression
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
enum Foo {
    A,
    B,
}

fn inc (x: &mut i32) -> i32
{
    *x = *x + 1;
    *x
}

fn inspect () -> i32 {
    let mut x = 0;
    let y = Foo::B;

    match (y, inc (&mut x))
    {
        (Foo::A, 0) => { return 0; }
        (Foo::A, 1) => { return 1; }
        (Foo::A, _) => { return -10; }
        (Foo::B, 0) => { return 2; }
        (Foo::B, 1) => { return 4; }
        (Foo::B, _) => { return -20; }
    }
}
```

I expected to see this happen: Compiles without error.

Instead, this happened: 
```
/home/dfaust/playpen/gccrs/match/tuple-side-effects.rs:20:18: error: expected [i32] got [(Foo{A = ( 0 ([C: 0 Nid: 4 Hid: 132 Lid: 1])), B = ( 1 ([C: 0 Nid: 6 Hid: 133 Lid: 2]))}, i32, )]
   16 |     match (y, inc (&mut x))
      |               ~   
......
   20 |         (Foo::A, _) => { return -10; }
      |                  ^
/home/dfaust/playpen/gccrs/match/tuple-side-effects.rs:16:5: error: failed to type resolve expression
   16 |     match (y, inc (&mut x))
      |     ^
/home/dfaust/playpen/gccrs/match/tuple-side-effects.rs:12:1: error: expected [i32] got [<tyty::error>]
   12 | fn inspect () -> i32 {
      | ^                ~
```

However simpler cases like
```rust
fn foo () -> i32 {
    let mut b = 6;
    let tup = (Foo::A, inc (&mut b));

    tup.1
}

fn bar () -> i32 {
   let mut x = 0;

    match inc (&mut x) {
        0 => { return 0; }
        1 => { return 1; }
        _ => { return -1; }
    }
}
```
Both compile with no error.

### Meta

- What version of Rust GCC were you using, git sha if possible. 
70a0039b82b3419820359c8a1552470e48b458f6, but behaves the same on a recent commit before #1458 was merged, so not a regression from that.
